I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) 2005 Country Programming Mission, the 
Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  confirmed  its  request  for  technical 
assistance (TA) to prepare a rural road development strategy. In response, an ADB Fact-
Finding  Mission  visited  the  PRC  in  June  2005  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
Government on the objectives, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, consultants’ terms of 
reference, and implementation arrangements for the TA. The TA is included in ADB’s 2005 
country assistance plan for the PRC.1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  In recent decades, the PRC has achieved rapid economic growth and poverty reduction. 
Its gross domestic product has grown more than 9% per year since the 1980s and the incidence 
of rural poverty fell from 33% in 1978 to just 2.8% in 2004. Propelling the country’s robust 
growth and drastic poverty reduction were massive investments in roads. The country’s highway 
network grew from 1.16 million kilometers (km) in 1995 to 1.86 million km in 2004, for an 
average annual increase of 6%. The length of expressways increased from 147 km in 1988 to 
34,287 km in 2004, a more than 100-fold expansion. Class I highways increased from 196 km in 
1980 to 33,522 km in 2004, or 29% per year on average. Despite the Government’s remarkable 
performance, transport conditions continue to pose a challenge for the remaining 30 million rural 
poor. Many of them live in areas that are partially or completely isolated, which increases their 
transportation costs and restricts their access to basic goods and services. It also keeps the 
poor from taking advantage of the job opportunities generated by the PRC’s economic growth. 
 
3.  The Ministry of Communications (MOC) classifies county, township, and village roads as 
rural roads, which totaled 2.9 million km in 2004, or 85% of the total road network of 3.3 million 
km. Of the total rural roads, 479,372 km are county roads, 945,180 km are township roads, and 
1,473,534 km are village roads. County roads are often found in urban areas,3 while village 
roads, which account for about half of rural roads, link farmers to markets within a locality. 
 
4.  Rural transport plays a huge role in economic development and poverty reduction in the 
countryside.  Rural  roads  directly  influence  the  daily  lives  of  the  rural  poor  and  contribute 
substantially  to  poverty  reduction.  The  construction  or  improvement  of  rural  roads  lowers 
transport costs, cuts travel time, and enhances the quality of transport services. In turn, rural 
roads encourage villagers to travel to markets, make more frequent use of educational and 
health facilities, and avail themselves of agricultural extension services. Reliable access to input 
and  output  markets  stimulates  higher  levels  of  production  in  cash  crop  farming,  thereby 
speeding up the transition from subsistence farming to a market economy. In addition, by 
reducing the distance that people have to travel to reach major roads, rural roads help diversify 
income sources, raise the productivity of poor households, and promote contact with other 
regions. The development of a rural road network is therefore critical for promoting efficient and 
sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction in rural areas and in the country as a whole. 
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 30 March 2005. 
3  Urban roads are defined as all roads within the boundary of a county or district that has been declared an urban 
county or district. A prefecture-level city comprises both urban and rural counties and districts, thus in such cases, 
cities control both urban and rural roads.

2     
5.  MOC is responsible for planning the national highway network, which totals 129,815 km, 
or 4% of the entire road network of 3.3 million km. Under MOC guidelines, the Provincial 
Communications Department (PCD) is responsible for the planning, development, maintenance, 
and  administration  of  the  provincial  highway  network.  PCD  and  municipal  and  county 
communications bureaus are tasked with planning and administering the rural road sector, 
including constructing and maintaining the rural road network. MOC provides PCD with policy 
guidance  and  technical  support  through  national  policies,  regulations,  and  design  and 
construction standards.4 
 
6.  While  national  and  provincial  road  networks  are  generally  adequate,  the  rural  road 
network is underdeveloped in terms of both quality and extent and does not provide access to 
large parts of the hinterland. Furthermore, most rural roads are in poor condition because of 
deficiencies  in  design  and  construction,  inadequate  maintenance,  damage  caused  by 
overloaded  vehicles,  and  insufficient  funding.  The  technical  standards  of  rural  roads  are 
extremely low: only 11% are class III or above. Village roads are even worse, with merely 2% 
being rated class III or above. Only 20% of county roads, 15% of township roads, and 9% of 
village roads are paved. About 71% of rural roads are dirt roads, making them highly vulnerable 
to bad weather. As a result, many townships and villages still depend on earth tracks that have 
no drainage system, making them unsuitable for motorized traffic and impassible during the 
rainy season. 
 
7.  The Government’s road development policies stress the importance of developing rural 
roads, particularly roads that would connect farmers to rural markets and thereby help reduce 
poverty.  During  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005),  the  Government  constructed 
approximately 72,000 km of rural roads at a cost of CNY60.9 billion. The Government will invest 
CNY100 billion more in rural roads during the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010), so that by 2010, 
paved roads will link all villages in the eastern part of the country, 80% of villages in central 
PRC, and 90% of villages in the western part of the country. 
 
8.  Despite the country’s extensive road investment plan during the 11th Five-Year Plan, it 
does not yet have an adequate planning system, particularly for rural roads. Currently, provincial 
planning departments prepare road development plans based on county plans while county 
plans are based on township plans. The primary objective of their plans is to connect all towns 
with  paved  roads  and  all  villages  with  all-weather  roads.  Authorities  in  lower  levels  of 
government consolidate individual projects to form provinces’ investment plans, but give little 
consideration  to  other  factors,  such  as  the  overall  network  and  the  economic  activities  in 
particular  areas.  Given  the  project-by-project  approach  and  the  fragmented  nature  of 
administrative responsibilities, sections of road to be constructed or improved are often selected in 
an ad hoc manner. Relatively little attention is paid to the integration of the rural road network. 
 
9.  Data  are  collected  in  rudimentary  form.  Basic  data  on  the  condition  of  roads  and 
bridges—road length, start and finish points, road surface type, road width, and features along 
particular sections—are kept at the county and township levels. However, monitoring is often 
hampered by the method to store the information: data are filed in printed form without cross-
indexing between local administrative authorities. A nationwide inventory of rural roads by 
province needs to be compiled using MOC’s functional road classification system and this

3
inventory will need to be updated on a regular basis. Therefore a more rigorous and centralized 
database must be established to ensure the availability of information for planning purposes. 
 
10.  Most  rural  road  projects  lack  geometric  and  structural  standards  with  which  local 
governments must comply,5 such as drainage and safety features. Also lacking are systematic 
processes and tools for assessing and monitoring the quality of the rural road network that are 
adapted  to  local  governments’  resources  and  capabilities.  Furthermore,  local  government 
officials tend not to understand the importance of drainage and suitable drainage structures in 
relation  to  road  safety  and  maintenance.  Finally,  there  are  no  requirements  for  pavement 
material  for  most  rural  roads,  which  affects  their  longevity.  Usually  the  gravel  used  is 
substandard and prone to damage from inadequate drainage or overloaded vehicles. 
 
11.  Comprehensive strategies to strengthen rural road planning and programming need to 
be established promptly to improve the integration and efficiency of the rural transportation 
network and ensure its consistency with development and land use plans. The strategies must 
take into account rural and agricultural development, national transport policy, road sector 
reforms, local government administration, and planning frameworks at the local government 
level. 
 
12.  Adequate  maintenance  is  crucial  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  rural  roads,  a 
responsibility of local administrative units. However, the quality of rural roads does not seem to 
be systematically monitored by the higher authorities concerned and  there is no comprehensive 
planning  for  rehabilitation.  Furthermore,  maintenance  planning  often  hinges  on  subjective 
assessments, mainly because of local governments’ lack of resources for maintaining their road 
networks. Little dissemination of the activities or knowledge needed to monitor performance is 
apparent across counties. While local authorities draft plans for routine maintenance work, 
periodic maintenance is rather budget driven, and a systematic, preventive approach is lacking. 
As a result, a backlog of work exists in relation to bringing the network up to a fully maintainable 
standard. 
 
13.  No official funding channel is available for the maintenance of township or village roads 
nor is a systematic arrangement in place whereby higher levels of government (PCD or MOC) 
can  fund  the  development  of  rural  roads.  Therefore  a  reliable  funding  mechanism  for 
maintaining  and  rehabilitating  rural  roads  must  be  designed,  one  that  includes  attractive 
incentives  (including  financial  perquisites),  to  help  local  governments  maintain  their  roads. 
Because funds for maintenance are limited, a simple method for evaluating and prioritizing 
maintenance  work  must  also  be  established  to  streamline  work  programming  and  ensure 
effective use of funds. 
 
14.  In addition to the lack of funds, the lack of qualified technical and managerial personnel, 
training resources, and equipment often hampers local governments’ maintenance efforts. To 
raise  performance  standards,  the  cost-effectiveness  of  maintenance  operations  must  be 
assessed to identify the types of work that could be better performed by private contractors. At 
the  same  time,  local  governments  must  develop  their  capability  to  contract  out  for  road 
maintenance. In tandem, start-up assistance must be extended to local road maintenance 
contractors in rural areas and ways to generate employment for the rural poor must be identified. 
A suitable performance monitoring system must also be put in place. 
 
                                                 
5  Geometric standards only apply to the construction of roads above class IV.

4     
15.  ADB’s poverty reduction strategy assigns high priority to rural infrastructure, including 
rural roads. By opening up new markets and thereby encouraging higher levels of agricultural 
production, rural  roads  promote  larger  rural income  streams  that  contribute  significantly  to 
poverty reduction. Rural infrastructure development should be combined with empowering local 
communities, promoting good governance through decentralization, and strengthening local 
government  institutions.  ADB’s  country  operational  strategy  for  the  PRC  emphasizes  the 
importance of developing the road infrastructure, including rural roads. In the road sector, the 
strategy’s key concerns include (i) supporting the formulation of a policy framework for a rural 
roads investment program, (ii) putting more focus on planning and maintenance systems, and 
(iii) increasing private sector participation. Given this background, the proposed TA will review 
the  status  of  the  rural  road  sector  and  develop  a  comprehensive  strategy  to  boost  the 
effectiveness of rural road investments for sustainable economic development and poverty 
reduction. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
16.  The TA aims to help the Government formulate and prepare a rural road development 
strategy to enhance the effectiveness of rural road investments in meeting the PRC’s rural 
transport needs. To achieve this objective, the TA will (i) undertake a detailed assessment of the 
rural  road  sector  in  selected  pilot  provinces,  in  particular,  of  planning,  programming,  and 
maintenance; (ii) identify strategic-priority projects to be included in the 11th Five-Year Plan for 
rural  road  development  in  line  with  the  Government’s  objectives;  and  (iii)  help  strengthen 
institutional capacity for implementing rural road interventions. This strategy will serve as the 
Government’s key document for strengthening the rural road sector in the 11th Five-Year Plan. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
17.  International consultants, supported by domestic consultants, will be engaged to help the 
Government prepare the rural road development strategy. The TA will be undertaken in close 
consultation with the national and local governments and will take into consideration all previous 
studies carried out by the Government and by ADB and other multilateral agencies. The TA will 
involve  analytical  research;  fieldwork;  training;  and  stakeholder  consultations  with  the 
Government, provincial governments, and local stakeholders. 
 
18.  Key activities include (i) reviewing development plans for rural roads; (ii) identifying 
issues  and  options  in  relation  to  development  needs,  policy  reforms,  and  regulatory 
requirements in line with the Government’s development goals; (iii) undertaking case studies in 
the provinces of Shandong, Inner Mongolia, and Shaanxi and assessing issues and options for 
the sector in each province; (iv) identifying high-priority projects to be included in the 11th Five-
Year  Plan  for  rural  road  development  in  each  of  the  pilot  provinces  and  preparing 
implementation  and  financing  plans;  (v)  preparing  a  rural  road  maintenance  manual;  (vi) 
developing a rural road development strategy that integrates an appropriate implementation 
framework and mechanisms for strengthening the planning, programming, and maintenance of 
rural roads and the institutional framework for implementing rural road interventions; and (vii) 
disseminating best practices through a national workshop.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $450,000 equivalent, of which $212,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $238,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government 
requested ADB to finance $350,000 equivalent to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$138,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from 
ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  MOC  will  finance  the  remainder  of  the  TA  cost  ($100,000 
equivalent), which will be used to cover office accommodation and other facilities and services 
required to implement the TA. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The TA will require about 22 person-months of consulting services (7 international and 
about 15 domestic) spread over 8 months, including fieldwork. The consultants will be engaged 
by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development 
Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of 
domestic  consultants.  A  team  of  international  consultants,  in  association  with  domestic 
consulting firm(s), will be engaged following the quality- and cost-based selection method, and 
biodata proposals will be required.  The international consultants will provide expertise in (i) 
transport policy and planning; and (ii) maintenance and management, particularly specialized in 
policy and regulation. The domestic consultants shall have expertise in (i) transport planning, 
policy, and regulation; (ii) maintenance, and (iii) management and institutional strengthening. 
Appendix 3 presents the outline terms of reference for consulting services.  
 
21.  MOC will be the executing agency and will be responsible for supervising and monitoring 
TA activities and for liaising with Government agencies and organizations. MOC will (i) ensure 
the cooperation of concerned Government agencies, and (ii) provide the consultants with the 
assistance needed to implement the TA. MOC and other ministries will provide appropriate 
policy guidance to the consultants. The TA is expected to begin in February 2006 and be 
completed  by  September  2006.  To  strengthen  institutional  capacity,  the  TA  will  finance 
overseas training programs in the areas of planning, programming, and maintenance. MOC will 
provide  the  consultants  with  all  relevant  materials,  recent  studies, and  reports  required  to 
implement the TA. The consultants will maintain close contact with MOC and keep MOC and 
ADB informed of their progress and findings. Tripartite meetings involving the Government, ADB 
staff, and the consultants will be held in the PRC to provide advice and guidance to the 
consultants and review their reports. The consultants will procure equipment in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
22.  The consultants will submit reports to ADB as follows: (i) an inception report 2 weeks 
following the commencement of services, (ii) an interim report 12 weeks after commencement, 
(iii) a draft final report 20 weeks after commencement, and (iii) a final report 2 weeks after 
receiving all comments from MOC. Within 4 weeks of the submission of the draft final report, a 
national workshop will be held in Beijing to disseminate the findings of the TA. Each report 
should be submitted in English and Chinese to Ministry of Finance, National Development 
Reform Commission, and MOC. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Rural Road Development Strategy, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  General 
 
1.  The  consultants  will  prepare  a  rural  road  development  strategy  to  enhance  the 
effectiveness of rural road investments in meeting the rural transport needs of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC). The consultants will (i) undertake a detailed assessment of the rural 
road sector, particularly in relation to planning, programming, and maintenance; (ii) identify 
strategic-priority projects to be included in the 11th Five-Year Plan for rural road development in 
line  with  the  Government’s  objectives;  and  (iii)  help  strengthen  institutional  capacity  for 
implementing  rural  road  interventions.  This  strategy  will  serve  as  the  Government’s  key 
document for strengthening the rural road component of the 11th Five-Year Plan. 
 
2.  Planning  and  Programming  [4.0  person-months  (team  leader)/8.0  person-
months domestic] 
 
2.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Review any proposed policy reforms, the recommendations of related studies, 
and the lessons learned from preparing and implementing previous and ongoing 
Asian Development Bank (ADB)-assisted projects. Review relevant documents 
related  to  trends  and  issues  in  rural  and  agricultural  development,  national 
transport  policy,  road  sector  reform,  local  government  administration,  and 
planning frameworks at the local government level and draw appropriate lessons 
for  the  conceptualization  and  implementation  of  the  rural  road  development 
strategy. 
(ii)  Review the literature on rural transport policy and existing documentation on the 
rural road situation in the PRC and provide a brief review and analysis of relevant 
past initiatives and more recent programs aimed at poverty reduction, drawing 
lessons of experience as appropriate. 
(iii)  Review the policy framework for rural roads in the PRC, detailing the legislative 
and  regulatory  environment  and  identifying  the  responsibilities  of  different 
government agencies at all levels as they pertain to rural roads. 
(iv)  Assess  roles  and  responsibilities  and  review  implementation  arrangements 
between local governments and the Ministry of Communications (MOC) for local 
government road infrastructure projects assisted by MOC. 
(v)  Establish the existing legal status of village roads, identify the implications for 
their  sustainable  development  and  maintenance,  and  make  appropriate 
recommendations. 
(vi)  Discuss and elaborate the existing situation and issues and options relating to 
key aspects of the situation, including  
(a)   transport sector planning, management, and coordination;  
(b)   road sector reforms; 
(c)   rural road infrastructure provision and maintenance including standards 
and classification, financing and management; 
(d)   planning framework at the local government level; 
(e)   local government administration;  
(f)   institutional framework for implementing rural transport interventions;  
(g)   capacity  for  delivering  rural  transport  interventions,  including  at  the 
community level; and  
(h)   methods for promoting labor-intensive road works.

classification system as defined by MOC and develop a workable process to 
update this inventory on a regular basis. Collect the necessary data, including 
road characteristics and conditions, from local government units. 
(viii)  Determine the extent and condition of the rural road network as it is and as it 
could be based on sample surveys, population distribution, and existing and 
potential economic activities using norms from the literature on acceptable levels 
of accessibility by settlements to different types of roads. 
(ix)  Review the standards of existing rural roads in several provinces and help refine 
them by incorporating prevailing international standards for rural roads, focusing 
on bridges and drainage and safety features. 
(x)  Formulate  systematic  processes  and  tools  for  assessing  and  monitoring  the 
quality of the rural road network adapted to the resources and capabilities of local 
government units. 
(xi)  Recommend workable approaches for efficient and integrated local road network 
management  and  development  planning.  Define  responsibilities  and  resolve 
overlaps among local government units and various national Government entities 
involved in rural road projects. Propose targets in terms of levels of service for 
each  category  of  roads  and  processes  and  tools  for  prioritizing  financial 
resources for maintaining, rehabilitating, and improving the local road network. 
(xii)  Undertake  case  studies  in  three  provinces—Shandong,  Inner  Mongolia,  and 
Shaanxi—and assess issues and options for the sector in each province, with 
particular attention to the planning, programming, and maintenance of rural roads 
and specifies actions for strengthening the institutional framework.

road development in each of the pilot provinces and preparing implementation

implementation  framework  and  mechanisms  for  strengthening  the  planning,

3.  Maintenance (3.0 person-month international/7.0 person-months domestic) 
 
3.  The consultants will 
(i)  Formulate strategies to enhance local government interest in road maintenance 
by proposing adequate incentives, including financial incentives, to encourage 
local  governments  to  better  maintain  their  roads;  and  designing  and 
implementing a communication campaign aimed at convincing local government 
decision makers of the benefits of proper road maintenance.  
(ii)  Assess the cost-effectiveness of rural road maintenance by local government 
units compared with maintenance by contracts with private entities and identify 
the types of works that could be better performed by private sector enterprises, in 
particular,  rural  road  maintenance,  and  evaluate  the  potential  benefits. 
Maintenance  options  may  range  from  simple  routine  maintenance  by  local 
villagers to maintenance contracts covering packages of roads to develop a 
viable local contracting industry. 
(iii)  Formulate  a  strategy  to  promote  private  sector  intervention  through  capacity 
building,  training  programs,  and  information  campaigns  targeting  local 
governments and local contractors. Consideration may be given to providing 
assistance, for instance, technical training, business planning, and small and 
medium enterprise finance, to get contractors started in rural areas. 
(iv)  Develop standard technical and administrative specifications to be used by local 
governments for competitive bidding in local road construction, rehabilitation, and 
maintenance. Identify the scope for public-private partnerships in rehabilitating 
and maintaining local roads. 
(v)  Provide recommendations related to institutional and financing frameworks for 
providing  and  maintaining  rural  transport  infrastructure  at  the  different 
administrative levels of government. 
(vi)  Formulate a sustainable funding mechanism to support the maintenance and 
rehabilitation  of  rural  roads.  The  proposed  mechanism  should  explore  cost-
recovery measures in line with the national Government’s intent to encourage 
local government units to raise some funds from their own resources and should 
provide  adequate  incentives,  including  financial,  to  encourage  better  road 
maintenance. Explore ways to increase revenues through a fuel tax, and assess 
appropriate fuel pricing levels. 
(vii)  Develop a rural road maintenance manual that incorporates all the requirements 
and recommendations identified. Provide outline procedures for each type of 
maintenance  activity  to  provide  the  necessary  guidance  for  resource 
requirements. Develop a suitable performance monitoring system. The manual 
should be in a modular form so that it can be readily adapted to users’ different 
requirements based on terrain and climate. 
(viii)  Propose a financing framework for rural road development that will define the 
priorities,  modalities,  and  conditions  for  Government  assistance  to  local 
government  road  development  projects;  identify  the  responsibilities  and 
harmonize the modalities of intervention of the various MOC- sponsored local 
road  projects;  and  define  the  role  of  Government  subsidies  in  rural  road 
development. The financing framework should enable local governments in poor 
areas to benefit from road improvement by providing them with more attractive 
financial  terms.  Assess  the  financial  resources  needed  to  implement  the 
proposed  framework,  which  should  be  realistic  in  terms  of  the  budgetary 
implications for national and local governments.
